author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Nobody Makes Films Like Alex Garland. But He Might Stop Making Them.
description: The man behind “Men” says of directing, “I don’t particularly enjoy it. It’s something I have to force myself to do.”
content: Alex Garland knows that calling his new film “Men” is a provocative act. “It’s quite interesting that such a short, simple word can be so freighted with massive and entirely subjective meanings,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: One Way to Do More for the Environment: Do Less With Your Yard
description: Every year we let more patches of our yard go wild, and every year more flowers appear in the uncut areas.
content: NASHVILLE — When I mention the new meadow I am cultivating where our front yard used to be, my adult children roll their eyes. The word “meadow” conjures the mental image of a sunny field of blooming wildflowers, but this one is a work in progress. A dream more than an actuality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘The Nutmeg Trail’ Goes Along the Spice Routes and Into the Kitchen
description: The food writer Eleanor Ford’s new book details flavor profiles and origins of spices, and decodes classic blends.
content: Over many years the use and evolution of spices became a subject of fascination and study for Eleanor Ford, a London-based food writer who has lived in Indonesia and Hong Kong. A result is not only her vast collection of spices, but also a new, colorful cookbook, “The Nutmeg Trail: Recipes and Stories Along the Ancient Spice Routes.” It peels back layers of history — spice by spice, starting with nutmeg — from the many seasonings that have elevated food since antiquity. Spice routes, trade and colonialism figure importantly in the text. Ms. Ford provides flavor profiles and origins of spices, and decodes classic blends with a focus on the Middle East, Asia and a snippet of Africa; she omits French vadouvan and quatre-épices. Spices shine in recipes like Keralan black pepper chicken, and superb green peppercorn asparagus. Glossaries, charts and maps categorize spices throughout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trump could be paid to post for his own start-up.
description: A new regulatory filing by the company in talks to merge with the Trump Media & Technology Group also warned that regulators may not let the deal go through.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump could be paid to post for his own start-up company and it remains unclear if securities regulators would allow its merger with a cash-rich shell corporation to go forward, according to a securities filing on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko and Marc Santora
title: Ukrainian authorities declare an end to the combat mission in Mariupol after weeks of Russian siege.
description: More than 250 fighters were evacuated from the besieged Azovstal complex, after holding out and sheltering civilians for weeks under near-constant Russian bombardment.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian authorities announced late Monday an end to their combat operation in the besieged city of Mariupol, where Ukrainian fighters have held out for weeks in the face of near-constant Russian bombardment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: A Partial List of Mass Shootings in the United States in 2022
description: The attack in which 10 people were killed at a supermarket in Buffalo was the country’s deadliest shooting this year.
content: The massacre in which 10 people were killed in a Buffalo supermarket on Saturday was the deadliest mass shooting in the United States so far this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Breathing, Dancing Art at the Met Museum
description: Bijayini Satpathy, a MetLiveArts artist in residence, pushed the borders of her Odissi classicism to meet the art around her.
content: One of the most ravishing dance events of recent years was the appearance by the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 2015. The majesty of the Temple of Dendur met its match in the moving sculpture of the dancers Bijayini Satpathy and Surupa Sen. Now Satpathy is back, this time on her own as the MetLiveArts artist in residence, with performances last weekend and the next in galleries around the museum. Ravishment has returned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Ben Bernanke Sees ‘Stagflation’ Ahead
description: The former chairman of the Federal Reserve has a new book out on Tuesday explaining the powers of the Fed and Congress to juice or slow our economy amid a supply-chain crunch and sky-high demand.
content: Standing in his kitchen one morning in Washington, D.C., and drinking a glass of lightly flavored water, Ben Bernanke is wearing a gray suit, a button-down shirt, no tie and a pair of Brooks running sneakers. He looks a far cry from his time at the Federal Reserve, where he presided as chairman for eight years during what was — until recently — considered the most precarious financial moment of the past half-century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Bloody Crossroads Where Conspiracy Theories and Guns Meet
description: The slaughter in a Black neighborhood in Buffalo is in line with a series of racist massacres that shows no signs of abating.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, you and I live in a state that has some of the toughest gun laws in the country. But that didn’t stop a teenager with a history of making threats from getting his hands on a semiautomatic rifle and mowing down 10 people at a supermarket in a Black neighborhood in Buffalo on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Johnson’s Softer Tone on Northern Ireland Trade Rules Belies Hard-Line Plans
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who traveled to Northern Ireland on Monday, also urged a power-sharing government in the wake of Sinn Fein’s victory in legislative elections.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson called for a return to politics-as-usual in Northern Ireland on Monday, even as his government was poised to outline legislation that could allow it to scrap parts of the trading system that has governed the North since Britain left the European Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: New Research Offers Clues as to Why Some Babies Die of SIDS
description: The study could pave the way for newborn screening — but the results still need to be corroborated by further research.
content: Scientists in Australia have found that some babies at risk of sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS, have low levels of an enzyme called butyrylcholinesterase (BChE) in their blood. Their study, published May 6 in the journal eBioMedicine, could pave the way for newborn screening and interventions if the results are corroborated by further research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: U.S. Senator From Maryland Suffers ‘Minor Stroke’
description: Chris Van Hollen, a Democrat, said in a statement that there were “no long-term effects or damage,” but that he would be under observation for a few days.
content: Senator Chris Van Hollen of Maryland announced late Sunday night that he was recovering from “a minor stroke,” the second Democratic lawmaker to fall ill from the ailment this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski, Rick Gladstone and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Further Russian Retreat Seen in East Ukraine, Another Setback for Putin
description: Russia appeared to shrink its already narrowed goals to take the Donbas region, as NATO and its two newest applicants, Sweden and Finland, practiced war games near Russia’s border.
content: KRAKOW, Poland — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia faced a series of setbacks Monday over the Ukraine invasion, as his faltering military appeared forced to further shrink its goals and an emboldened NATO practiced war games with the alliance’s two newest applicants on his country’s doorstep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: The Believer, a Beloved Literary Magazine, Goes Home After a Risqué Detour
description: The magazine, bought by a marketing company, briefly hosted clickbait content. Scandal ensued. After a flurry of negotiation, it is now back with its first publisher, McSweeney’s.
content: An unusual article appeared in April on the website of The Believer, a literary magazine known for publishing writers like Nick Hornby and Zadie Smith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Cheney says House Republican leaders have ‘enabled’ white supremacy.
description: The Wyoming Republican called on her party to “reject and renounce” the ideology and those who espouse it.
content: Representative Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming and a former member of G.O.P. leadership in the House, on Monday called out her party’s leaders for enabling the spread of white nationalism after a gunman who believed racist ideology killed 10 people at a Buffalo supermarket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In ‘The Letters of Thom Gunn,’ an Unusual Mix of Pleasures
description: Gunn was not a confessional poet, but he spilled his guts in rowdy, funny, filthy, intensely literate correspondence.
content: Thom Gunn bought his first motorcycle, a secondhand Harley, in Texas during the spring of 1955. He was teaching in San Antonio before going to study writing at Stanford.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Jambon Americano, Made In Iowa
description: La Quercia Cured Meats in Norwalk has introduced a new line of cured hams, dry-cured with sea salt and spices, in four varieties.
content: La Quercia Cured Meats, the Norwalk, Iowa, producer of charcuterie made from pork that’s often heritage breeds, has introduced a new line of cured hams called Jambon Americano. The ham is dry-cured with sea salt and spices, no additives, similar to how prosciutto is made but with shorter aging. The end result is less intense and also less expensive than prosciutto, suitable for sandwiches, a charcuterie plate or slivered in pasta dishes. There are four varieties: honey and herb, black pepper and cherry (these two are the most delicate); spicy, and sweet and spicy (both more robust).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: How Often Can You Be Infected With the Coronavirus?
description: The spread of the Omicron variant has given scientists an unsettling answer: repeatedly, sometimes within months.
content: A virus that shows no signs of disappearing, variants that are adept at dodging the body’s defenses, and waves of infections two, maybe three times a year — this may be the future of Covid-19, some scientists now fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Doughnut Plant Introduces ‘Wonder Wheel’ Ice Cream Sandwiches
description: The sandwiches are made on split doughnuts with ice cream flavors like coffee and peanut butter-milk chocolate.
content: To accompany the warming weather, Mark Isreal, the owner of the Doughnut Plant, has introduced the Wonder Wheel: a cake doughnut ice cream sandwich. The name is a mouthful, and each sandwich is a delicious one. Mr. Isreal said he has been working on them for years. They’re split, lightly coated with milk, dark or flavored white chocolate and filled with ice cream made in-house. The six ice cream flavors are coffee, green matcha, tres leches, strawberry, dark chocolate and peanut butter-milk chocolate. Let them sit a room temperature for about 10 minutes to soften.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Diamond Hands: The Legend of WallStreetBets’ Review: Is This Loss?
description: In this documentary, the Reddit users who spawned the GameStop gold rush recall their speculation creation.
content: The documentary “Diamond Hands: The Legend of WallStreetBets” starts with the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, as new traders began to use their stimulus checks to try the stock market. The most bullish traders gathered on the subreddit WallStreetBets, where get-rich-quick dreamers share tips for undervalued stocks. At the end of 2020, GameStop was among their juiciest prospects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: The ‘E-Pimps’ of OnlyFans
description: Clever marketers have figured out how easy it is to simulate online intimacy at scale, ventriloquizing alluring models with cheap, offshore labor.
content: On a warm January afternoon in Miami, Jayson Rosero sat by the pool and stared at his phone. He was spending his day as he often does: trying to grow his business, Think Expansion, which is a marketing agency — sort of. Rosero has called his line of work “e-pimping,” and it’s a pretty apt name. Think Expansion manages OnlyFans pages on behalf of more than 30 women, and as a full-service agency, Rosero and his employees handle every aspect of running the accounts. They market them on social media; they write all of their daily posts; they even handle direct messaging sales, impersonating the women in conversations with their subscribers in order to sell erotic videos. That afternoon, Rosero was looking to expand his roster. Wearing a snug short-sleeve hoodie, he scrolled through numerous Instagram messages he’d sent to women that day. All of them said essentially the same thing: I know you’d make a lot of money with me; I want to work with you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia’s Faltering Campaign
description: Plus climate’s role in Australia’s upcoming election and a Covid-19 protest at Peking University.
content: After a series of military setbacks, Moscow now appears to be focusing on a narrow objective: widening its holdings in Ukraine’s eastern region of Donbas. But even there Russia may be forced to scale back its ambition to take most of eastern Ukraine, according to the Institute for the Study of War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Met’s ‘Heirloom Project’ Marks the 10th Anniversary of Its Islamic Wing
description: The gift shop at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will showcase a number of items made by artisans from Islamic countries.
content: To mark the 10th anniversary of its Islamic Wing, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has added a number of items made by artisans in Islamic countries to its gift shop in what it is calling the “Heirloom Project.” It’s meant to be a showcase for crafts. Among them are gift boxes of Selamlique from Istanbul — exceptional Turkish delight, also called loukoum — the chewy, paste-like candies. They’re fashioned into elegant little blocks in four flavors: rose, citrus, mastic and pomegranate, coated with almonds, then covered with white or dark chocolate and dusted with gold leaf powder. A box of six of each, $25, is only available in the store in the museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Amber Heard Recounts Unraveling of Marriage to Johnny Depp
description: The defamation trial involving the actors is entering a new stage as Ms. Heard faces aggressive cross-examination from Mr. Depp’s lawyers.
content: Amber Heard testified on Monday in the defamation case brought by her ex-husband, Johnny Depp, that she filed for divorce and for a restraining order against him in 2016 after two blowout fights that made her fear for her safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch and Luke Vander Ploeg
title: Buffalo Shooting Highlights Rise of Hate Crimes Against Black Americans
description: The federal data shows a recent spike in assaults, threats and incidents of bias.
content: The racist slaughter at a Buffalo grocery store on Saturday is the latest episode in a troubling rise of violence against African Americans, built upon historic racial fault lines and a polarized social climate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Starbucks will cover travel expenses for employees seeking abortions.
description: In a memo on Monday, the company said it wanted to ensure that its employees had “access to quality health care.”
content: Starbucks announced on Monday that it would reimburse travel expenses for employees who need abortions and cannot get them within 100 miles of their homes, joining the small group of companies that have moved to protect employee abortion access as the Supreme Court appears likely to soon overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: When Should You Tip?
description: Do you tip when eating a sit-down meal? What about at a fast-food restaurant, or a coffee shop?
content: How often do you tip? Do you see tip jars or touch-screen systems for tipping in your neighborhood businesses? What about ice-cream parlors, bakeries or movie theaters?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Hear the Weird Sounds of a Black Hole Singing’
description: In this lesson, students will learn how NASA is “sonifying” the universe and how these sounds might change our understanding of the most enigmatic entity in the cosmos.
content: Featured Article: “Hear the Weird Sounds of a Black Hole Singing” by  Dennis Overbye
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka, Shawn Hubler and Eduardo Medina
title: California Church Shooting Was ‘Hate Incident,’ Sheriff Says
description: The man who opened fire on a Taiwanese congregation in Laguna Woods, Calif., killing one and injuring five, was motivated by political hatred, the Orange County Sheriff said.
content: LAGUNA WOODS, Calif. — Gathered to celebrate a beloved former pastor, snapping photographs of their Sunday church luncheon, the members of the Irvine Taiwanese Presbyterian Church did not pay much attention, at first, to the 68-year-old stranger in their midst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Rare Kind of Filly Dazzles at the Racetrack
description: Sodashi, who won the Victoria Mile on Sunday in Tokyo, has a rare genetic anomaly and may be the greatest thoroughbred of its kind.
content: Sodashi won the Victoria Mile on Sunday with a closing rally and received an especially loud roar from the fans at Tokyo Racecourse. The cheers did not come exclusively from those who had bet her to win at 5-1. The filly has become a sensation in Japanese horse racing circles because of her color: pure white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: How Buffalo Suspect’s Racist Writings Reveal Links to Other Attacks
description: Filled with hate, the screed describes a mass shooting at a grocery store and connects it with a belief shared by gunmen in previous massacres.
content: In an online screed full of neo-Nazi references, the 18-year-old New Yorker accused of going on a shooting spree this weekend at a Buffalo supermarket connected himself to a slurry of hateful ideologies. He also claimed allegiance to a group of violent killers across six countries responsible for racist murders reaching back more than decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Rachel Woolf
title: After a Midrace Heart Attack, Triathlon Champ Is Headed Back to the Start Line
description: Timothy O’Donnell nearly died from a heart attack at the Miami Challenge last year. Now it’s all about getting back to the Ironman World Championship in October.
content: For Timothy O’Donnell, hours of denial gave way in the emergency room of a South Florida hospital late on the night of March 13, 2021, when the trauma care specialist called the resuscitation team and told it to stay close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Schweber and Andy Newman
title: Mother Charged With Murder After Daughter, 9, Is Found Dead in Brooklyn
description: The girl had cuts and bruises to her head and bite marks on her body when investigators arrived at her Crown Heights home on Sunday.
content: A Brooklyn woman was charged with murder on Monday in the death of her 9-year-old daughter, who had cuts and bruises to her head and bite marks on her back when she was found the day before in their apartment, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Racist Massacre in Buffalo: A Place for Young People to React
description: An invitation to post your thoughts, feelings and questions.
content: Most young people coming to this forum likely already know the basic facts about what happened in Buffalo on May 14: A teenage gunman entranced by a white supremacist ideology known as replacement theory opened fire at a supermarket, methodically shooting and killing 10 people and injuring three more, almost all of them Black, in one of the deadliest racist massacres in recent American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: JetBlue goes hostile in its takeover bid for Spirit Airlines.
description: The carrier made a tender offer valued at $3.2 billion and said it was willing to pay more if Spirit cooperated with an acquisition.
content: JetBlue said Monday that it was taking its offer to acquire Spirit Airlines directly to that carrier’s shareholders, after Spirit’s board rejected a takeover proposal and decided to stick with its plan to merge with Frontier Airlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Jonah E. Bromwich and Ashley Southall
title: How guns are taken away under New York’s ‘red flag’ law.
description: Questions have been raised about why the law was not invoked against the Buffalo shooting suspect, Payton S. Gendron.
content: Since New York’s so-called red flag law took effect in 2019, judges have issued 589 orders barring people from possessing firearms because they pose a danger to themselves or others, according to the State Office of Court Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. and Abbott Reach Agreement on Baby Formula to Try to Ease Shortage
description: The company said production could resume in about 2 weeks and store shelves would be restocked several weeks later.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday reached an agreement with Abbott Laboratories on the steps needed to reopen the company’s shuttered baby formula plant, which could begin to ease the shortage of infant formula that has frightened and exasperated parents nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Adirondack Chairs
description: Nothing says summer like a pair of these classic outdoor lounge chairs.
content: A hefty outdoor seat with a laid-back posture and wide, flat arms, the Adirondack chair has a lot to recommend it. It generally stays where you put it, resists harsh weather and has arms that double as cocktail tables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: If a Company Responds to Social Pressure, That’s Progress
description: It’s a sign that we at least agree that racism and homophobia are bad.
content: In last week’s newsletter, I had a conversation with the philosopher Olúfẹ́mi O. Táíwò about the nature of dissent in an era when almost every message, however revolutionary in origin, gets processed and then ultimately defanged through the practice of “elite capture.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Russia’s Shrinking Goals
description: Russian forces now appear focused on seizing a smaller portion of eastern Ukraine.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: N.Y.C. urges people to wear masks indoors but stops short of requiring it.
description: City health officials urged New Yorkers to wear medical masks indoors and to take other precautions.
content: Citing high community transmission and rising hospitalizations from a fifth wave of coronavirus cases, New York City health officials on Monday strongly recommended that all individuals wear medical-grade masks in offices, grocery stores and other public indoor settings citywide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: P.S.G. Player Benched for Refusing to Wear Rainbow Jersey
description: Idrissa Gueye faced criticism after he missed a game rather than wear a shirt designed to support an anti-homophobia initiative. He skipped the same game last year.
content: Idrissa Gueye traveled south to Montpellier with his Paris St.-Germain teammates for the team’s league game on Saturday but wound up watching it from the stands. Gueye was not injured, his coach said after P.S.G.’s victory: He “had to leave the team for personal reasons.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Family Camp’ Review: Born to Be Mild
description: There’s little new in this comedy about parents and kids on a church outing in the wilderness.
content: Dad humor abounds in “Family Camp,” a vanishingly mild comedy that resembles other films about parents and kids bumbling in the wilderness. The lessons about being good to your folks are the same; “family is family,” to quote the absolutely undeniable title of one song in the film. But this summer trip, replete with cabins (or yurts) and goofy activities, is a church outing: the family that prays together, glamps together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: The West’s Scramble for Gas Could Enrich and Empower Tiny Qatar
description: As the United States and Europe seek to deprive Russia of its oil and gas income, their leaders hope Qatar can help fill the void.
content: RAS LAFFAN INDUSTRIAL CITY, Qatar — Over the past quarter-century, the tiny Persian Gulf state of Qatar has dispatched increasing amounts of natural gas to a growing list of customers around the world, amassing profound wealth and acquiring a geopolitical importance it would otherwise lack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: NATO to fast-track Nordic applications to join.
content: Jens Stoltenberg, the NATO secretary general, announced yesterday that the security bloc would grant fast-track membership to Sweden and Finland. The move raises the pressure on Vladimir Putin, who justified Russia’s invasion of Ukraine by what he cast as the need to keep the military alliance away from his country’s borders. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Problem With Elon Musk’s Vision of a Self-Driving Future
description: Our documentary explores Tesla’s difficulty in making automated driving a reality.
content: Watch our new documentary on Friday, May 20, at 10 p.m. on FX and Hulu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: The ‘Hamlet’ Chord: A Composer’s Music of Indecision
description: Brett Dean, whose adaptation of the classic play is at the Metropolitan Opera, discusses the four notes that embody Hamlet’s dilemma.
content: One of the boldest things about Brett Dean and Matthew Jocelyn’s “Hamlet,” which runs at the Metropolitan Opera through June 9, is the way that it treats some of the most famous lines in English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amos Zeeberg
title: What’s Down the Road for Silicon?
description: Meet the new materials overpowering the electric economy.
content: The story of modern electronics is often equated with the relentless advancement of the silicon-based microchips that process information in our computers, phones and, increasingly, everything else. Moore’s law has become a well-known summary of how those chips become ever more compact and powerful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Matthew Haag, Michael Levenson and Kellen Browning
title: The suspect recorded months’ worth of preparation in an online chat log.
description: The messages posted on Discord lay out in excruciating detail the racist and violent ideology that drove the young man who now stands accused of the massacre at a grocery store in Buffalo.
content: For months before the mass shooting in Buffalo that killed 10 people, a teenager mulled potential targets, posted racist and antisemitic memes and messages and updated his plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Redrawn New York Map Nullifies Democrats’ Gamble to Gain House Seats
description: The court-drawn lines would increase competition for seats in Congress, and pit longtime Democratic incumbents against one another.
content: Earlier this year, Democratic leaders in New York made a brazen gamble: With the national party’s blessing, they created a congressional map that promised its candidates as many as three additional House seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Putin’s New Problems
description: An update on the second phase of the war in Ukraine.
content: The first phase of the war in Ukraine was largely a failure for Russia. The second phase is not going very well so far either.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Victims Include Security Guard Hailed as Hero
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 16, 2022.
content: “Don’t tell me you’re a friend of our community and you don’t address this today at your pulpit. If you do not stand behind those holy desks and acknowledge that there are still people who hate Black people, you can go to hell with the shooter for all I care.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Are You Happy? Your Boss Is Asking.
description: To some, the pursuit of workplace happiness — and its price, like an $18,000 “happiness M.B.A.” for managers — can seem like a corporate attempt to turn feelings into productivity.
content: Garry Ridge, who runs the chemical company WD-40, has a leadership style guided by two sources — Aristotle, and the BlackRock chief executive Larry Fink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Dallas Mavericks Stun the Phoenix Suns in Game 7
description: The Suns had the best record in the N.B.A. in the regular season and went to the finals last year. This time, they couldn’t make it out of the second round.
content: A Game 7 in the N.B.A. playoffs is supposed to be the most thrilling, intense type of game, where the high stakes bring out the best in both teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.7 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-style retreat in Palm Springs, an Edwardian house in Palo Alto and a renovated 1948 home in Sonoma.
content: Stan Sackley, a prolific midcentury architect, designed this house and a number of others in the neighborhood. The sellers, who work in interior design, used his original plans to guide their renovation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: A Pitching Debut at 42 That Somehow Did Not Set a Record
description: Albert Pujols was the life of the party in the Cardinals’ 15-6 win against the Giants. But he fell short of being the oldest player to pitch for the first time.
content: That Albert Pujols took the mound as a pitcher for the first time at age 42 and did not set a record is all you need to know about the depth of Major League Baseball’s record books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Fringe Conspiracy Theory, Fostered Online, Is Refashioned by the G.O.P.’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about replacement theory, its role in the racist massacre in Buffalo and how it manifests in mainstream politics and media.
content: Please note: This lesson features disturbing details about the racist massacre in Buffalo and the white supremacist ideology behind it. Before your students learn more, you may wish to begin with Teaching in the Wake of Violence, a collection of ideas from our friends at Facing History and Ourselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: On ‘Barry,’ Sarah Goldberg Has Learned to Love TV
description: This Canadian star of the HBO dark comedy came up as a committed stage actor, but television gave her an opportunity for a different kind of performance.
content: LONDON — Over two and a half seasons on “Barry,” Sally Reed, the aspiring star played by Sarah Goldberg, has become one of the most complex characters on television, inviting both sympathy for her Hollywood struggles and contempt at her overweening self-absorption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and John Koblin
title: Madison Avenue’s Biggest Event Returns, to a Whole New World
description: In the three years since the television industry’s biggest companies pitched their shows to advertisers in person at the so-called upfronts, the entertainment industry has been flipped on its head.
content: For the first time in three years, the circus is coming back to town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Jürgen Blin, Who Went 7 Rounds Against Ali, Dies at 79
description: In 1971, Blin was a working-class fighter from Hamburg and a top contender in Germany. Ali was coming off a loss to Joe Frazier and needed to get back in shape.
content: BERLIN — Even before the little-known semipro boxer Jürgen Blin faced Muhammad Ali in a ring in Switzerland in 1971, he knew as well as anyone that he was fated to lose the fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Liz Alderman
title: Yellen Looks to Get Global Tax Deal Back on Track During Europe Trip
description: The Treasury secretary is traveling to Warsaw, Brussels and Bonn, Germany, this week at an uncertain time for the global economy.
content: WARSAW — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen arrived in Europe this week to join U.S. allies in confronting multiple threats to the world economy: Russia’s war in Ukraine, soaring inflation and food shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Furman
title: Living the #ConventLife
description: Sisters are joining TikTok to offer a window into their cloistered experiences. “We’re not all grim old ladies reading the Bible,” one nun said.
content: Before she entered the Community of St. John Baptist in 2012, Claudette Monica Powell performed in an acoustic rock duo and an improv comedy troupe in Los Angeles. Now she goes by Sister Monica Clare, sings in a church choir in Mendham Township, N.J., and posts matter-of-fact videos about convent life on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: One Million Deaths
description: More Americans have died from Covid-19 than in all of the country’s wars combined.
content: The United States is poised to reach a previously unthinkable milestone: one million deaths from the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Rescuing the Cuisine of Besieged Mariupol, Recipe by Family Recipe
description: For one Ukrainian American home cook, recording and sharing the dishes she grew up eating is an act of resistance.
content: Food memories from childhood summers tend to stick. Olga Koutseridi, a graduate student adviser at the University of Texas at Austin, formed hers in Mariupol, the small city on the Black Sea whose name has become synonymous with the worst devastation Russia has inflicted on Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: The Little Red Boxes Making a Mockery of Campaign Finance Laws
description: Democratic candidates are all-but scripting ads for super PACs and dark-money groups to do their bidding — in plain sight.
content: Facing a threat from his left flank, Representative Kurt Schrader of Oregon wanted to send an urgent message to allies ahead of his upcoming primary: It was time to go on the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: In Rebirth for NATO, Europe Unites in Face of Putin’s Ambition
description: Sweden’s and Finland’s embrace of NATO after decades of neutrality is a clear statement that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has ended an era of European illusions about Moscow.
content: The decisions by Finland and Sweden to abandon the neutrality they adhered to for decades and apply to join NATO is the strongest indication yet of a profound change in Europe in the face of an aggressive Russian imperial project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore and Karen Yourish
title: A Fringe Conspiracy Theory, Fostered Online, Is Refashioned by the G.O.P.
description: Replacement theory, espoused by the suspect in the Buffalo massacre, has been embraced by some right-wing politicians and commentators.
content: Inside a Pittsburgh synagogue in 2018, a white man with a history of antisemitic internet posts gunned down 11 worshipers, blaming Jews for allowing immigrant “invaders” into the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Renault strikes a deal to exit Russia, for now.
description: The French company will sell its stake in Russia’s largest automaker for one ruble, with the option of returning within six years.
content: PARIS — The French automaker Renault announced Monday that it was exiting Russia in a deal negotiated with the Russian government that would allow Renault the option of resuming business in the country at a future date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: The F.D.A. is expected to soon authorize Pfizer-BioNTech’s booster for 5- to 11-year-olds.
description: Given that the age group has the lowest coronavirus vaccination rate of all eligible Americans, public health experts are not expecting a rush for the booster.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is expected as early as Tuesday to authorize a booster shot of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for children 5 to 11, according to multiple people familiar with the plan. That would make those children the youngest Americans eligible for the additional shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
title: Pandit Shiv Kumar Sharma, Master of the Santoor, Dies at 84
description: He single-handedly elevated a 100-string instrument little known outside Kashmir into a prominent component of Hindustani classical music.
content: Pandit Shiv Kumar Sharma, an Indian musician and composer who was the foremost exponent of the santoor, a 100-string instrument similar to the hammered dulcimer, died on Tuesday at his home in Mumbai. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: They Were at Tops When the Shooting Started. This Is How They Survived.
description: Workers at the East Buffalo grocery store were tending to customers when a car pulled up, and a mass shooting began.
content: BUFFALO — On weekends, the employees at the Tops Friendly Market in East Buffalo tend to be younger, the ones unable to work weekdays, often because of school. Cashiers, shopping-cart attendants, shelf stockers — their manager, Lorraine Baker, 57, calls them “my babies.” One of them, Nia Brown, 20, was just back to work on Saturday after having had her own baby seven weeks earlier, a daughter named Aniyah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Republican ‘Chaos’ in Pennsylvania Threatens to Upend the Midterms
description: The G.O.P. thought it had 2022 all figured out. Then along came Kathy Barnette and Doug Mastriano.
content: To a degree surpassing any other contest in the 2022 midterms so far, Donald Trump has poured his personal prestige into Pennsylvania’s Republican Senate primary race, which is going through a final spasm of uncertainty as Kathy Barnette, an insurgent candidate with a sparse résumé, gives a last-minute scare to Trump’s pick, Dr. Mehmet Oz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Grace Young Is the Recipient of the Annual Julia Child Award
description: An expert in Cantonese Home Cooking and an activist, Ms. Young plans to use the $50,000 grant to support Chinatowns.
content: This year the cookbook author Grace Young is the recipient of the annual Julia Child Award, given by the Julia Child Foundation for Gastronomy and the Culinary Arts to those who have influenced how America cooks, eats and drinks. Her background and expertise is Cantonese and Chinese home cooking and wok traditions, and over the last two years, with the rise of anti-Asian incidents, Ms. Young has become an activist. She supports Chinatowns across the country, especially New York’s Chinatown in Manhattan. She has also donated some of her family’s rare porcelain from Shanghai and an heirloom wok to the Smithsonian National Museum of American History, where a replica of Julia Child’s kitchen is on display. She will receive a $50,000 grant from the foundation at a ceremony in Washington on Oct. 13, and said she plans to use it to support Chinatowns and their traditional restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Why Are There So Many Shampooers in New Jersey?
description: You can learn a lot about America by asking what people do for a living in different places.
content: You can learn a lot about America by asking what people do for a living in different places. For example, guess the U.S. metropolitan area where bartenders are most concentrated. Ocean City, N.J. How about dentists? Lake Havasu City-Kingman, Ariz. Economists? The greater Washington area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross, Vivian Giang and Anna Schaverien
title: Bernanke’s Economic Warning
description: The former Federal Reserve chair warns that the U.S. could be headed for a period of “stagflation.”
content: Ben Bernanke says the U.S. economy, for the first time since the 1970s, could be heading toward a period of stagflation. Bernanke, the former Federal Reserve chair who headed the central bank during the 2008 financial crisis, warns that the nation is headed for a situation, much like the 1970s, where Americans were losing their jobs but still facing higher prices at the grocery store and at the pump. “Even under the benign scenario, we should have a slowing economy,” Bernanke told DealBook, in an exclusive interview with Andrew ahead of Bernanke’s new book. The book, “21st Century Monetary Policy: The Federal Reserve From the Great Inflation to Covid-19,” is publishing tomorrow. “So there should be a period in the next year or two where growth is low, unemployment is at least up a little bit and inflation is still high.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Núria López Torres
title: An Intimate Look at Mexico’s Indigenous Seri People
description: The identity of the Seri is integrally tied to their natural environment, which in recent years has been susceptible to an increasing number of existential threats.
content: A light wind laden with the scent of the sea softened the stifling heat: The temperature had reached 108 degrees Fahrenheit, and it was only 10 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden
title: Taking Aim at Left-Leaning Voters, Macron Names a Woman Prime Minister
description: Élisabeth Borne, the minister of labor who previously was in charge of the environment, will be the second woman to hold the post in France.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron appointed Élisabeth Borne, the low-key minister of labor and a former minister of the environment, as his new prime minister on Monday, in line with his promise to prioritize environmental issues in his second term and a long-expressed wish to select a woman for that role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Grief and Fury Sweep Though Buffalo
description: “This is someone who had hate in their heart, soul and mind,” the Buffalo police commissioner said about the attacker at the Tops supermarket.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll follow developments in the Buffalo mass shooting. We’ll also look at four people who helped catch the subway attack suspect last month — and now are seeking official help with their immigration issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
title: Biden Approves Plan to Redeploy Several Hundred Ground Forces Into Somalia
description: The president also signed off on targeting about a dozen Shabab leaders in the war-torn country, from which Donald J. Trump largely withdrew in his final weeks in office.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has signed an order authorizing the military to once again deploy hundreds of Special Operations forces inside Somalia — largely reversing the decision by President Donald J. Trump to withdraw nearly all 700 ground troops who had been stationed there, according to four officials familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Etelka Lehoczky
title: Two Nostalgic, Fiercely Feminist Graphic Novels
description: “Time Zone J,” by Julie Doucet, and “Flung Out of Space,” by Grace Ellis and Hannah Templer, inhabit their feminism in different and fascinating ways.
content: Goodness gracious: Julie Doucet has a new graphic novel out! This is staggering news. Renowned since the ’90s for the brutally frank, aggressively complex “Dirty Plotte” as well as numerous other books, Doucet quit drawing more than 20 years ago. This long quiet period has, naturally, accorded her a staggering level of prestige in the comics world. Just last month she became the third woman ever awarded the Grand Prix lifetime achievement award at the distinguished Angoulême International Comics Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Amid a Worsening Formula Shortage, Mothers Are Asked: ‘Why Not Breastfeed?’
description: The current crisis has exacerbated an already emotionally charged health care issue in the U.S.
content: Before having her third child last month, Joelyz Lugo had planned to breastfeed, but her daughter’s difficult birth derailed such plans. While in the neonatal intensive care unit, her baby needed to be fed formula, and when the pair finally tried breastfeeding, the baby struggled to latch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Russia Planned a Major Military Overhaul. Ukraine Shows the Result.
description: Russia wanted to build a leaner, more flexible fighting force and eliminate waste, bureaucracy and corruption. But entrenched, Soviet-era practices endure.
content: Army vehicles were so decrepit that repair crews were stationed roughly every 15 miles. Some officers were so out of shape that the military budgeted $1.5 million to re-size standard uniforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Kendrick Lamar, Mortal Icon
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning social commentator rapper returns after five years with “Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers,” an album about what’s broken on the inside.
content: Kendrick Lamar has long extracted maximum power from his blend of the interior and the global, making him a particular kind of generational superstar — one who shoulders the weight of others. In a few places on “Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers,” the rapper’s fifth studio album, he laments from the top of the mountain he’s spent the last decade climbing. These are depleted, lonely incantations: “I can’t please everybody,” “I choose me, I’m sorry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: After 32 years, McDonald’s plans to sell its Russia business.
description: “This is a complicated issue that’s without precedent and with profound consequences,” said Chris Kempczinski, the chief executive of McDonald’s.
content: After more than three decades in Russia, McDonald’s — an icon of U.S. lifestyle and capitalism — has put its Russia business up for sale as it works to leave the country completely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Millet
title: How Does a Man Become an Island?
description: The antihero of Karen Jennings’s latest builds a stone wall between himself and the world that broke him.
content: It may not be a sure thing, but it’s a good bet: If you write a work of fiction that forgoes a redemptive arc or happy ending, and you also happen to be a woman, sooner or later you’ll get asked the question that’s not unlike being told to smile by passers-by on a sidewalk: Why darkness?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: From Voodoo to MAGA to Buffalo
description: How the paranoid style took over the G.O.P.
content: I never thought I’d say this, but I miss voodoo economics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Della Volpe
title: Young Americans Are Stressed. They Are Angry. And They Can Swing Congress.
description: Donald Trump, abortion rights and student loan debt create a narrow window for President Biden and Democrats to regain their footing.
content: Millions of newly minted college graduates are about to enter a scorching job market, but many are still held back by feelings of hopelessness and depression. Less than one in 10 Americans between 18 and 29 years old describe ours as a “healthy democracy.” Most are convinced that both political parties cater to elites over people like them and that our politics cannot meet the challenges of the times. More than anything, “happiness and stability” are what youth seek, but even that appears out of reach at a time when they’re readying to launch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Estonia’s Tough Voice on Ukraine Urges No Compromise With Putin
description: Kaja Kallas, the prime minister, remembers the repression of life under Soviet rule and sees the same brutality in occupied Ukraine, which she believes is fighting for all of Europe.
content: TALLINN, Estonia — Kaja Kallas, now 44, grew up in the Soviet Union, which had annexed her country, Estonia, after World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: At Montpelier, Slaves’ Descendants Will Share Power With White Board Members
description: The board of Montpelier, President James Madison’s Virginia estate, voted 11 new members to the board after months of disagreement.
content: After months of conflict, the foundation that runs President James Madison’s Virginia estate agreed on Monday to accept 11 people recommended by a group of descendants of enslaved people who worked there to its governing board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Cortes Is Brilliant Yet Again as Yankees Top White Sox
description: Nestor Cortes’s unbelievable journey continued with a career-high eight innings.
content: CHICAGO — When Nestor Cortes was in high school, his father used to complain when he wandered off the mound while he was pitching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, Joy Dong and Isabelle Qian
title: Students Protest Covid Lockdowns at Elite Beijing University
description: Authorities moved quickly to censor videos and photos that showed students at Peking University demonstrating.
content: A group of students at a campus of China’s elite Peking University protested strict Covid-19 lockdown requirements on Sunday, arguing that the measures were poorly communicated and unfair. The government quickly moved to censor videos and photos that spread on China’s internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Why Kamala Harris’s Chief Spokesperson Left the White House
description: Symone Sanders talks about her pivot from working at the White House to covering it on her new cable show.
content: Symone Sanders left a meteoric political trajectory to join the media. After working on Bernie Sanders’s 2016 campaign, advising Joe Biden’s 2020 campaign and serving as Vice President Kamala Harris’s chief spokesperson for her first year in office, Sanders is pivoting to become the host of her own MSNBC show, “Symone.” This makes her the latest in a revolving door of former Washington insiders turned media anchors (think George Stephanopoulos, Nicolle Wallace, Jen Psaki and Kayleigh McEnany).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: verve
description: This word has appeared in 136 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word verve has appeared in 136 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 6 in “The Deeper Meaning of Elvis in Australia” by Damien Cave:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Michael C. Bender
title: G.O.P. Senate Candidate in North Carolina Thrives as 2 Key Backers Squabble
description: Representative Ted Budd is proving the political potency of pairing endorsements from Donald Trump and the Club for Growth, the on-again, off-again allies.
content: HENDERSONVILLE, N.C. — Rick Griswold, a 74-year-old lifelong Republican, doesn’t know much about Ted Budd, the congressman he plans to support on Tuesday in the party’s Senate primary election. But he knows exactly why he’ll cast his ballot for Mr. Budd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Bad Bunny Has the Biggest Week of 2022 on the Chart, for Now
description: Future broke the record last week; Kendrick Lamar is poised to set a new bar next week. Blockbuster season on the Billboard album chart has finally arrived.
content: The blockbuster stage of the year’s music release calendar has arrived, with big numbers for Bad Bunny’s latest album on this week’s Billboard chart, and even bigger sales expected for Kendrick Lamar’s long-awaited, just-released return to next week’s chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What to Know About the Orange County Church Shooting
description: Congregants jumped in and subdued the attacker, believed to be an Asian man in his 60s.
content: Amid a nationwide explosion in gun violence that shows few signs of easing, a gunman opened fire inside an Orange County church on Sunday and killed one person and critically injured four others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Jonah E. Bromwich, Andy Newman and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Buffalo Suspect Planned Attack for Months, Online Posts Reveal
description: The 18-year-old was able to buy an assault-style weapon even though he had been held for a mental health evaluation in high school.
content: BUFFALO — A cache of online postings suggests months of preparation and planning preceded Saturday’s racist massacre in Buffalo and shows how the suspect evaded a state law that could have prevented him from owning a gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Akiko Iwasaki
title: The Answer to Stopping the Coronavirus May Be Up Your Nose
description: Why nasal vaccines for Covid could be so effective.
content: The Covid-19 vaccines authorized for use today were developed at unprecedented speed and surpassed expectations in how well they worked. The billions of people who are protected by them have avoided severe symptoms, hospitalization and deaths. These vaccines are a scientific success beyond measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle J. Anderson and Deborah Tuerkheimer
title: The Thinking About Consent Has Evolved Drastically. This Code May Turn the Clock Back.
description: Didn’t we learn anything from the #MeToo movement?
content: A major effort to update the model criminal code on rape may actually undermine new understandings of consent advanced by the #MeToo movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Ryan Mac
title: After Buffalo Shooting Video Spreads, Social Platforms Face Questions
description: Gunmen say they are influenced by online screeds and broadcasts of past shootings. Do social media sites have a responsibility to rein in hateful and violent content?
content: In March 2019, before a gunman murdered 51 people at two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, he went live on Facebook to broadcast his attack. In October of that year, a man in Germany broadcast his own mass shooting live on Twitch, the Amazon-owned livestreaming site popular with gamers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Katherine Massey, Buffalo Shooting Victim, Wrote to Newspapers Calling for Gun Control
description: In her most recent letter to The Buffalo News, Ms. Massey denounced the city’s “escalating gun violence” and called for crackdowns on illegal out-of-state gun trafficking.
content: Years before Katherine Massey, 72, was killed in Saturday’s mass shooting in Buffalo, she wrote several commanding letters in local Buffalo publications urging stronger gun control laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Elon Musk says a lower price for Twitter is ‘not out of the question.’
description: Mr. Musk has been creating confusion around whether the Twitter deal will close, causing the social media company’s share price to fall.
content: Elon Musk threw another curveball at his takeover of Twitter on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Queen Latifah, Amanda Seyfried Honored by Variety
description: They joined four others celebrated in the magazine’s Power of Women issue.
content: “What a week for women it’s been,” said Sarah Silverman at a dinner celebrating Variety magazine’s Power of Women issue on May 5. She was referring to the leaked Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kieran Pender and Matthew Abbott
title: How the Long Recovery From Bush Fires Could Decide Australia’s Election
description: The fires that tore through the country in late 2019 and early 2020 are history, but halting recovery efforts have kept memories vivid and anger fresh.
content: COBARGO, Australia — On a recent sunny day in the hills behind Cobargo, a village in southeastern Australia, local volunteers were hard at work installing a bathroom for the Jee family, which had waited more than two years for a proper one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Vincler
title: Nick Cave Goes Underground
description: Amid the noise and teem of the Times Square station, the artist’s mosaic Soundsuits feel more alive than they often do in the silence of museums.
content: For an artist best known for “Soundsuits” that produce a variety of percussive effects when worn, Nick Cave’s public project, “Each One, Every One, Equal All,” has found a fittingly noisy home in the New York subway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zinara Rathnayake
title: The Many Sides of Curry Leaves
description: The distinctive aroma of this earthy herb is the backbone of so many recipes for good reason.
content: At my parents’ home in Kurunegala, Sri Lanka, as at many others across South Asia, curry leaf trees grow in the backyard, suffusing the air with a slight earthiness. That scent only intensifies when the fresh leaves sizzle in coconut oil, an integral step in so much of our home cooking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: How the Rangers Beat the Penguins in Game 7 in Overtime
description: Artemi Panarin scored on the power play to send the Rangers to a second-round series against the Carolina Hurricanes after they had faced a three-games-to-one deficit.
content: Time was running out on a season of unexpected success for the Rangers. They were losing by a goal and the anxiety was rising at Madison Square Garden. To most people outside the Ranger universe, it would have seemed as if their terrific run was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules for Ted Cruz in Campaign Finance Case
description: The Texas senator challenged a federal law that put a $250,000 cap on repayments of candidates’ loans to their campaigns using postelection contributions.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled in favor of Senator Ted Cruz in his challenge to a federal law that limits how political campaigns can repay candidates for money they lend their own campaigns. The ruling was the latest in a series of decisions dismantling various aspects of campaign finance regulations on First Amendment grounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Could Death Penalty Shift Spare Man Charged in Bike Path Terror Attack?
description: Trump-era prosecutors demanded capital punishment for Sayfullo Saipov, accused of mowing down eight people on a New York cycle path with his truck.
content: Shortly after Sayfullo Saipov, an immigrant from Uzbekistan, was arrested on suspicion of using a truck to kill eight people on a Manhattan bike path in 2017, President Donald J. Trump declared on Twitter, “SHOULD GET DEATH PENALTY.” Ultimately, Jeff Sessions, his attorney general, authorized federal prosecutors to seek capital punishment should Mr. Saipov be convicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rikki Novetsky, Rachelle Bonja, Alexandra Leigh Young, Lisa Chow, John Ketchum and Chris Wood
title: The Racist Theory Behind So Many Mass Shootings
description: Replacement theory has once again been cited by a mass shooter, this time in Buffalo, N.Y. What is it and how is it becoming more mainstream?
content: Over the weekend, an 18-year-old man livestreamed himself shooting 13 people and killing 10. Within hours it became clear that the shooter’s intent was to kill as many Black people as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Merry Wives’ and George Carlin
description: A recording of a Public Theater Shakespeare show airs on PBS. And a documentary about George Carlin debuts on HBO.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 16 - 22. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Russia sought to create a leaner, meaner military. But entrenched, Soviet-era practices endure.
description: Army vehicles were so decrepit that repair crews were stationed roughly every 15 miles. Some officers were so out of shape that the military budgeted $1.5 million to re-size uniforms.
content: Army vehicles were so decrepit that repair crews were stationed roughly every 15 miles. Some officers were so out of shape that the military budgeted $1.5 million to re-size uniforms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 16, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 16, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Afghanistan?
description: Can you find Afghanistan on a map? What else do you know about this country with 39 million people?
content: Can you find Afghanistan on a map? What else do you know about this country with 39 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Four Myths About PTSD
description: Insights and advice from experts
content: Insights and advice from experts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Nadja Popovich
title: Here Are the Wildfire Risks to Homes Across the Lower 48 States
description: New data was used to calculate fire risk to residential and other properties. The threats are rising.
content: New data was used to calculate fire risk to residential and other properties. The threats are rising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsea Matiash
title: The Latest on Abortion Rights in the U.S.
description: Get caught up on the latest news about reproductive rights and the birth control.
content: Get caught up on the latest news about reproductive rights and the birth control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston and Matt McCann
title: Scenes From Sunday’s Lunar Eclipse
description: Earth's shadow fell over the moon on Sunday, creating the astronomical phenomenon some call a blood moon.
content: Earth's shadow fell over the moon on Sunday, creating the astronomical phenomenon some call a blood moon.
source.name: The New York Times

title: $2.7 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-style retreat in Palm Springs, an Edwardian house in Palo Alto and a renovated 1948 home in Sonoma.
content: A midcentury-style retreat in Palm Springs, an Edwardian house in Palo Alto and a renovated 1948 home in Sonoma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Total Lunar Eclipse Turns Moon Red
description: Eclipse watchers gazed up as the Earth shadow fell over the moon, causing it to appear copper-red in a phenomenon some call a blood moon.
content: Eclipse watchers gazed up as the Earth shadow fell over the moon, causing it to appear copper-red in a phenomenon some call a blood moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: 1 Dead, 5 Injured in California Church Shooting
description: Jeff Hallock, the Orange County, Calif., undersheriff, praised the “exceptional heroism and bravery” of churchgoers who overpowered the gunman before deputies arrived.
content: Jeff Hallock, the Orange County, Calif., undersheriff, praised the “exceptional heroism and bravery” of churchgoers who overpowered the gunman before deputies arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Picture-Perfect Rice Bowl
description: Here’s a good reminder of how weeknight-friendly pork tenderloin can be.
content: Good morning. I love this recipe for a hoisin-glazed pork bowl with vegetables, even if I can’t find watermelon radishes, won’t make it with black or brown rice and can never get my sugar snap peas to look as beautiful as the ones Simon Andrews prepared for David Malosh’s photograph (above). Make your bowl the best that you can. It’s invariably pretty and always an elegant meal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Buffalo Massacre: A Deadly Mix of Racism and Guns
description: After another massacre, readers urge not only gun control but also addressing domestic terrorism. Also: A Covid death; lawmakers need to govern; Republican contortions.
